event: Taíno people, an Arawakan-speaking group, settle the island of Hispaniola.
Christopher Columbus lands on Hispaniola; establishes La Navidad, first European settlement in the Americas.
Santo Domingo founded by the Spanish on the eastern part of the island.
Treaty of Ryswick formally cedes western third of Hispaniola to France; becomes Saint-Domingue.
Saint-Domingue becomes France’s most profitable colony due to sugar and coffee plantations using enslaved African labor.
Massive slave revolt begins the Haitian Revolution.
Toussaint Louverture issues constitution for autonomous colony, abolishing slavery.
Napoleon sends troops to reassert control; Louverture captured and deported to France.
Jean-Jacques Dessalines declares independence; Haiti becomes first Black republic and second independent nation in the Americas.
France demands and Haiti agrees to pay reparations in exchange for diplomatic recognition.
U.S. invades and occupies Haiti, citing instability and foreign interests.
U.S. withdraws troops but maintains economic and political influence.
François 'Papa Doc' Duvalier elected president; establishes brutal dictatorship.
Jean-Claude 'Baby Doc' Duvalier succeeds his father at age 19, continuing authoritarian rule.
Duvalier regime overthrown; exiled to France.
Jean-Bertrand Aristide elected president in Haiti’s first democratic election.
Military coup ousts Aristide; reinstated in 1994 with U.S. and UN support.
Aristide ousted again amid unrest; UN peacekeeping mission established.
Massive earthquake kills over 200,000 and devastates Port-au-Prince.
Hurricane Matthew causes widespread destruction.
President Jovenel Moïse assassinated; political instability intensifies.
Gangs expand control amid political vacuum; international community calls for aid and intervention.
